awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MRI: Development of Apparatus for the Cold Molecule Nuclear Time-Reversal EXperiment (CeNTREX)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support the purchase of equipment and parts needed to construct the apparatus for a new experiment known as CeNTREX, the Cold molecule Nuclear Time-Reversal experiment. CeNTREX is a collaborative effort to detect evidence for new types of fundamental forces and particles, through precise measurements of magnetic resonance signals from nuclei embedded in the polar molecule thallium fluoride. The goal of the CeNTREX experiment is to detect a particular deformation in the shape of an atomic nucleus, known as a nuclear Schiff Moment. This will advance the progress of science because a Schiff Moment along the spin axis of a nucleus can arise only in the presence of fundamental interactions that are not symmetric under reversal of the direction of time. Interactions of this type can be mediated by new, as-yet undetected, particles that are predicted to occur in some theoretical models that extend the current Standard Model of particle physics. A Schiff Moment of size large enough to be detected with the projected sensitivity CeNTREX could indicate the existence of new particles with mass well above that of the heaviest known particles - and even beyond the reach of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).  Hence, CeNTREX will provide one of the few known ways to search for physics beyond the Standard Model associated with particles too massive to be created at the LHC.  An experiment with the fundamental discovery potential of CeNTREX can also capture the interest of the general public and raise the level of excitement about science. In addition, design and construction of the CeNTREX apparatus will provide opportunities for training several young scientists in instrumentation development. This type of precision measurement science exposes students to a wide range of intellectual and technical subfields, and provides unusually broad training in experimental physics that benefits development of the scientific workforce of the nation.

The existence of an asymmetric charge distribution such as an electric dipole moment (EDM) or a Schiff moment (SM) along a particle's angular momentum axis requires violation of time reversal (T) symmetry, which is equivalent to the more widely-discussed phenomenon of CP violation.  Observation of an EDM or SM within a few orders of magnitude of current limits would be evidence for phenomena outside the Standard Model of particle physics theory.  Furthermore, there are strong motivations from particle theory and cosmology to expect an EDM or SM in this experimentally-accessible range.  Discovery of an EDM or SM could illuminate the mechanism responsible for the observed matter-antimatter asymmetry of the universe, which remains one of the grand challenges of cosmology and particle physics.  Moreover, new physics at the TeV scale (the range of energy not being explored at the LHC), carrying new CP-violating phases, naturally give rise to EDM and SM near the current experimental limits.  Hence any advance in sensitivity to SMs pushes the frontier of particle physics in a manner complementary to current efforts at the Large Hadron Collider.   The CeNTREX apparatus will be developed by integrating a wide array of subsystems - many custom designed and built - including vacuum systems, a molecular beam source, lasers, optical control and detection systems, microwave control and transmission systems, precise magnetic field measurement and control systems, and high voltage systems. The conceptual design of CeNTREX builds from recent advances using the properties of diatomic molecules to amplify signals due to new fundamental forces, and in precisely detecting and manipulating molecules.  This novel apparatus will use a cryogenic beam of diatomic molecules to make the world's most sensitive measurement of a SM.  Detailed estimates of the first-generation measurement using CeNTREX are projected to yield a 30-fold increase in sensitivity, relative to the current state of the art, to certain types of time-reversal symmetry violating interactions that could be responsible for the cosmological matter-antimatter asymmetry in the Universe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF funds were used to develop a new apparatus called CeNTREX, the Cold Molecule Nuclear Time-Reversal Experiment. The experiment will address a long-standing mystery in physics - why is the universe dominated by matter?

The Standard Model of modern physics describes the fundamental particles of nature and their interactions, successfully describing all laboratory experiments. However it cannot explain why, in the early universe after matter and antimatter were created in equal abundance, more of the matter survived annihilation to form the matter-dominated universe of today. This fundamental puzzle can be explained by the existence of a new class of particles and interactions beyond those of the Standard Model that lead to an imbalance between matter and antimatter. Large particle colliders such as the LHC attempt to produce and detect these new particles, so far without success.

CeNTREX will attempt a sensitive indirect detection of these hypothesized new heavy particles to solve the mystery. It relies on the fact that the same imbalance in the behavior of matter and antimatter (an unexplained symmetry-breaking) is expected to show up in another effect on the properties of everyday matter. For instance, the nuclei in many atoms possess a nuclear magnetic moment (like a compass needle) and they will precess in a magnetic field. If they possessed a hypothesized property called a nuclear Schiff moment, the nuclear spin would also precess in an electric field. This property violates the same symmetry properties built into the Standard Model discussed above. However the existence of new particles beyond the Standard Model can perturb the behavior of nuclei. This is a well known quantum phenomena in which particles such as nuclei are never alone, they interact with a sea of particles that appear and disappear out the vacuum in a manner which changes their bare properties, and in this case, induce a permanent Schiff moment.

CeNTREX searches for a Schiff moment in thallium because heavy nuclear are expected to have larger Schiff moments induced by new physics. The thallium fluoride molecule is used because the molecule is easily polarized to make a large effect electric field at the thallium nucleus, making the Schiff moment interaction with the electric field easier to detect.

This instrumentation project was focused on the design and construction of the apparatus. This starts with a cryogenic source of thallium fluoride molecules that forms an intense slow beam. The molecules emerging in the beam are in many possible quantum states but only one is useful for the Schiff moment measurement. So the beam source is followed by a stage in which UV lasers and microwaves are used to transfer molecules out of the less useful states into the single useful state ("rotational cooling"). Having more molecules in the desired quantum state optimizes the sensitivity of the experiment to the Schiff moment. After cooling, the molecules are manipulated using microwaves into a quantum state in which they are sensitive to forces from an electric quadrupole lens. The lens focuses the molecules, maximizing the number of molecules that can make it through the rest of the apparatus. After focusing the molecules are manipulated into the quantum state useful for the Schiff moment measurement. The molecules then enter a long region with a strong electric field. For fundamental reasons, the Schiff moment will lie along the nuclear spin vector. The interaction of the Schiff moment with the electric field causes the Schiff moment and hence nuclear spin vector to rotate (precess) about the electric field. This precession is detected after the electric field region in a state detection stage. Here UV lasers and sensitive light detection techniques are used to detect the quantum state of the thallium fluoride molecules in a manner which is sensitive to the nuclear spin direction. By reversing the electric field combined with other reversals, the rotation of the Schiff moment in the electric field can isolated from other possible sources of nuclear spin rotation, and limits placed on the size of the Schiff moment.

The students and postdocs working on the project developed significant technical and scientific skills. They learned precision techniques in molecular spectroscopy and the manipulation, control, and detection of molecular quantum states. They learned about cryogenic techniques, high vacuum and high voltage systems, generation of high power UV laser light, laser frequency stabilization, and microwave systems. They will be valuable additions to the scientific and technical work force.

The project will soon make the first measurement of the Schiff moment of thallium using modern techniques with precise quantum state manipulation and detection. New limits on the Schiff moment will be used to test the viability of new models of physics that seek to explain the dominance of matter over anti-matter in the universe. This is of considerable importance in fundamental physics, and an intriguing puzzle of much broader interest.
